name: Helen
title: Greek - Helen of Troy
role: The Face That Launched a Thousand Ships, Daughter of Zeus, Most Beautiful Woman
summary: Helen of Troy, daughter of Zeus and Leda, was famed as the most beautiful woman in the world. Her abduction by (or elopement with) Paris caused the Trojan War, launching the thousand ships of the Greek expedition. In Homer's Iliad, she is portrayed with complexity - self-loathing yet divine, blamed yet sympathetic. She weaves a tapestry of the war fought for her sake and longs for her first husband Menelaus and daughter Hermione.
description: Helen, the face that launched a thousand ships, was daughter of Zeus and Leda, born from an egg after Zeus seduced her mother as a swan. Her beauty was so extraordinary that all the Greek kings sought her hand. In Homer's Iliad, she appears on Troy's walls with Priam, identifying Greek warriors, and weaves a tapestry depicting the war fought for her sake.
epithets: Face that launched a thousand ships
attributes: Complex portrayal - both victim and cause

homeric_context.role_in_epic: The cause of the war; appears on Troy's walls and weaves tapestry of the conflict
key_books: Book 3 - Teichoskopia (viewing from the walls), identifies Greek warriors for Priam
Book 3 - Aphrodite brings her to Paris after his defeat by Menelaus
Book 6 - Appears with Paris, self-critical of her situation
Book 24 - Laments Hector as one of the few kind to her in Troy
famous_scenes: Teichoskopia - viewing from the walls with Priam (Book 3)
Forced by Aphrodite to go to Paris (Book 3)
Weaving the tapestry of the war (Book 3)
homeric_context.characterization: Homer portrays Helen with remarkable complexity - divine yet self-loathing, desired yet lonely, blamed yet sympathetic

divine_parent: Zeus (father, who seduced Leda as a swan)
divine_protector: Aphrodite (gave her to Paris, protected her)

oath_of_tyndareus.description: When all the Greek kings sought Helen's hand, Odysseus suggested they all swear to defend whomever she chose. This oath bound them to wage war on Troy when Paris took her.
oath_of_tyndareus.significance: The foundation of the Greek expedition against Troy
